text:
Good morning. Welcome to our second session,
"The Clinical Challenge of Managing a Pandemic,"
featuring professor Ashish Jha

of the Harvard Chan School
of Public Health and Harvard Medical School. Our moderator is HBS
Professor Robert Huckman.

Please note that a
recording of this session will be made available to
a broader public audience.

If during the Q&A, you're
called on to pose a question, your name and voice will
be part of that recording.

Over to you, Rob. Great. Thank you, Willy. And I want to thank everyone
for being online with us today,

particularly the
members of the RC class. We are thrilled to have
you all here in this way,

and to continue the discussion
that got off to a great start with Ken Chenault and Karen
Mills just a little while ago.

So I want to welcome today
Professor Ashish Jha, who is the K.T. Li Professor
of International Health

and Health Policy at the
Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health. He's also the Director of
the Harvard Global Health

Initiative. And he is also a practicing
internist at the VA Boston health care system.

He received his MD and
MPH degrees from Harvard. He was a chief resident
at UCSF before completing

his fellowship at Brigham
and Women's here in Boston. Now, if you see Ashish's
face, he may look familiar.

In the last few
weeks, he has been on pretty much every
major news outlet

I can think of, ranging from
CNN, PBS, Fox News, and MSNBC.

So in true bipartisan
fashion, I think it's important to note
that he has said during one

of those interviews
that the coronavirus is

an insidious disease that
does not respect state borders or national borders.

And by the way,
doesn't care if you're a Democrat or a Republican. Now, before I get
started, I want

to just mention one more
thing about Ashish, which is that in late
February of this year, he was named the next Dean of
the Brown University School

of Public Health,
effective September 1. So he's got a ton on
his plate right now.

And despite the pain
of our losing him as a member of the
Harvard faculty, we know that Ashish's
international focus

and reputation will continue
to benefit all of us, and frankly benefit the
world for many years to come,

and we'll all have a chance
to continue to benefit from his wisdom and insight. Now, for today, we
actually get a chance

to do that directly and locally
just with our group of now 440 participants.

And so with that, I'd
like to welcome Ashish. Ashish, it's great
to have you here. Rob, thank you for both an
excessively kind introduction,

and for inviting me. It's going to have a lot of fun. I'm looking forward to it. I knew you'd tell me that. You're a very
modest person, and I

knew you'd say it's
excessively kind, so I've done my first job well. So I want to just jump right in
and note that, Ashish, you've

been certainly a repeated and
very early observer of the fact

that the US response
to the coronavirus has been both too slow
and started too late.

Can you tell us what
you see is truly the major reason for that? Because it could be
that it's political.

It could be that it's
because of something about us as Americans, and how we respond
when we see a crisis that

is coming our way. Or it could frankly
be some other factor entirely having to do with
availability of resources.

Can you give us
your sense of what the biggest issue is there? Yeah. And Rob, thanks for both
having me on and getting us

started there. What's interesting
is-- so I think by every objective
measure-- and I'll

get into what those objective
measures are in a second-- every objective measure
in the American response has been slow.

We've been playing catch-up. What's interesting
is we're not alone.

And I think-- and I don't
know how to articulate this very well, but when the history
of this pandemic is written,

and we look back to
countries that responded well versus countries that did
not, it's not just America.

It's a lot of Western
democracies-- others too, by the way-- that have really been
caught flat-footed.

In some ways, the
American response is almost singularly
bad, but we are not alone

in how badly we've done this. And that is interesting. And I don't think the
problem is democracy,

but I don't know what part
of our governance structure really failed us. So let's talk specifically
about why I say it's been slow.

We knew this virus was
spreading across China and had good reasons
to believe it

was going to land
in the United States by somewhere between
mid and late January. And we can argue, was it January
15, or was it January 30?

Doesn't matter. And we spent a good four to
six weeks just doing nothing

to prepare. So what are the things
we needed to do? We needed to get a testing
regime up and running.

And the failures of
the testing regime have been well-documented. Happy to get into that
if it's necessary.

But we just could not figure
out how to get a test up and running and
widely deployable. Second, we had a very
good sense by mid January

of the impact it was going to
have on the health care system. We saw it in Wuhan. We saw health care systems
there getting overwhelmed.

We saw the building of the
1,000-bed hospital in 10 days.

And we did not spend the last-- from, again, mid January
through mid March, we should have been preparing.

We should've been
building ventilators. We should've been getting
personal protective equipment. There's a whole set of things
that we knew we would need,

we should've been
getting, and we didn't. And we really didn't communicate
to the American people

what was coming. And that may be, in some ways,
the biggest failure of all.

Because a big part of
leadership and crisis management is communicating
to people, even

with all the
uncertainties people have, of what's coming down the pike. Actually, there's a great piece
by Michaela Kerrissey, who's

a professor at the business
school, recent graduate, and Amy Edmondson, a professor
at the business school,

just I think out yesterday
or day before about-- In HBR, yeah. In HBR. Fabulous piece about leadership,
and what great leadership

looks like, and what the
costs of bad leadership is. And I think everybody
should read that.

And we really did have
this catastrophic failure across all of these things. And we are in a
national lockdown,

I think in large
part because of that. We continue to struggle with
these very basic things.

And the notion that a
country with our size, creativity, resources,
has had to shut down

because in some places, we
don't have enough swabs, in some places, we can't
do a test, it's really--

it's surprising to me. And I have to tell
you, I've been a little surprised
at how flatfooted

we were as a country. You did raise a
point, and then you said we can talk
about it later, so I'm

going to pick up
on that, which is about the connection with
democracy and response

in this case. Do you feel that there's
a fundamental disconnect or lack of flexibility
that a democracy has in

responding to this, or is
it our particular democracy? Yeah, it's a very good question.

And again, there are
people around here-- Archon Fung, for instance,
at the Kennedy School, who are real experts
on democracies

and how they function. I'm not one of them. And of course, being a
big fan of democracy,

I tend to want to defend it. And so I'll give you my
defense where I don't think it's democracy, per se. South Korea did a really
good job on responding.

They're a democracy. Germany has done
a pretty good job of responding, better than us. They're a democracy.

I do think-- and
of course, China did an abysmal job of
responding initially, and they're not a democracy.

So I don't think
it's about democracy. It is clearly something
about governance and ability

to make decisions. Trust in government. It's a set of other
factors that, again, I

think people much
more expert than me are going to have to sort out. But it is remarkable
how some countries

did a pretty good job and others
have just done an abysmal one. Yeah. Well, I want to pick
up on another piece

from your initial
comments, and certainly from the writings that
you've done recently

and the appearances you've done. You've been a huge advocate for
increasing the level of testing

in the United States. I think there have been many
voices that have suggested we also need to do that.

And you've continued to
do that even as, say, our first set of hotspots in the
US have started to perhaps hit

their initial plateau. I won't call it a peak,
because it doesn't seem to be a peak, but a plateau.

So thinking of New York, and
New Jersey, and those areas. But I will note that
even during that time,

I don't know when
you made this change, but you changed your Twitter
name to Ashish, quote,

"I'm still focused
on testing" Jha. And I think I'm probably then
asking this a bit rhetorically,

but I have thick skin, and
I'm going to give it a go. But are we at a
point where the virus

has gotten so
pervasive in the US that the value of testing for
active infection is perhaps

decreasing, while maybe the
value of testing for immunity

might be increasing? And should we be shifting our
focus of testing at this point, or is there still a lot of value
in the active virus testing.

A great question, and I will
say, no, no, no, no shifting.

Let me walk you through why. And I actually am a huge fan
of the serology testing that's

started appearing already. I think it will provide
enormous amounts of value. But we shouldn't
confuse or overestimate

what the serology
testing will do. So let me take like two minutes
and talk through testing.

So if you begin at the
top, we have a virus, and we have a completely
susceptible population.

Meaning most Americans--
it's a novel virus-- have never encountered
this virus before. So all of us are vulnerable to
being infected from this virus.

So the question-- in any basic
epidemiologic model, what will happen is you introduce
a new virus into a susceptible

population, it will take off. And the speed at
which it will take off is the R0, how many people
does the average person infect.

And it'll keep going,
and keep going, and keep going, and infecting
more and more people until it starts encountering
large numbers of people who've

been previously
infected, and then it'll start slowing down until
it hits so many people have

been infected that
it hits herd immunity and the virus
essentially peters out. That's how this stuff works.

So there have been
places and countries that have said, oh, let's
just go through that and have herd immunity. The problem with that
approach, of course,

is massive numbers of people die
and health systems get crushed. So we think that's
not a great strategy.
So how do you prevent that? Well, you want a vaccine. That's what you want. But we don't have a vaccine.

So if you don't
have a vaccine, how do you prevent person
A, who's infected, from giving it to person
B, who's not infected?

There are two ways. Actually, there's one way. Make sure person A doesn't
come in contact with person B.

So if you don't
know who's infected, you put in social distancing. Just shut the
entire economy down.

Everybody does everything
by Zoom and virtually. And Rob, you and I are--

I can't infect you,
and you can infect me right now because we're
talking to each other virtually and we're physically
far from each other.

So social distancing
is the crude way of making sure person A
doesn't affect person B.

But social distancing
has massive costs. We've shut the economy down. If you want to let the
economy start functioning,

people are going to start
interacting with each other. In which case, person A will now
come in contact with person B

and infect them. How do we prevent
that in a context where the world is open again?

You got to identify that
person A is infected, and you got to pull
them out so person B can go around and be safe.

The only way you can identify
that person A is infected is by testing for
active infection.

So there is no other way. It's social distancing
or testing and isolation.

I don't know a third
path for stopping the spread of the virus. OK.

Now, couple of things
about that testing. Once the infection gets
very out of control,

testing and isolation
alone won't work. It won't alone work,
which is why we had to put in social distancing.

If we had a fabulous
testing infrastructure back in February, we could have
probably avoided all of this.

But we didn't. So you have to put
in social distancing to shut everything down and
bring the infection rates way,

way down. Once you do, and you open
up the economy again,

infection rates are going
to start rising again. And that's when you implement
a very vigorous testing

and isolation strategy. If you put in a testing
and isolation strategy while you're shut
down-- by the way, it does help the shutdown move
faster and have more benefit.

So even now, it's useful. But the moment we decide we're
going to end social distancing, we have to do it. Let's talk a little bit
about serology testing.

And serology comes
in two flavors. There's one flavor that
everybody talks about,

which is IgG, which
is essentially looking for immunity. Did you at some point in
the past get infected,

and if you did, do you have
an immune response to it now? We know that there are
probably a lot of people

out there in the community
who've been infected, but either didn't know it
or couldn't get tested. So as of this morning, there
are about 600,000 Americans

who are known to have
been infected with COVID. So if you asked me, how
many people have actually

been infected, the
answer's I don't know. We'll know more when
we do serology testing. But if you said,
what's your best guess,

I would say easily
10 times that. So instead of 600,000,
easily 6 million Americans.

Well, that's pretty good. It means that maybe 2% of the
population has been infected. Probably not enough that
you can use that information

to open the economy. You can't run the economy
with 2% of the population. Then there are people who
say, could be 100 times.

Maybe there are 60
million Americans who have been infected. That would be fabulous.

I'm skeptical that 100
times have been infected. Could I be wrong? I could absolutely be wrong.

And if it turned out that 60
million Americans have already been infected and most of them
have recovered, my goodness,

that would be awesome. So we're going to
all pray for that, but I'm not counting on that. My guess is 10 or 20 times
as many, so 6 to 12 million,

in which case we still
have a long way to go. So serology's very helpful,
but not for opening and running

the economy. You need to be able to
make sure person A who's infected is identified
and separated

so person B doesn't
get the infection. It's that simple. Yeah. And we can come back--

we will-- to talking about
this reopening question. I want to hit on
one other piece, though, when you talk
about the numbers infected.

Also thinking a
bit about something we've heard a great deal
about in the last week, which is about the disproportionate
burden of this disease

on certain populations. I think when we initially
heard about the disease, we were told, this
is going to be

something that's going
to particularly hit the elderly hard and the
medically compromised very hard.

What we've learned as
this has played out in several of our
larger urban areas is that it's also hitting
African-American populations

very hard, those with lower
economic means very hard,

and arguably many of our
service workers too very hard. And so the question of this
disproportionate effect--

you're someone who's
long studied disparities in health care, both at the
domestic and international

levels. How do you see the
lessons maybe that we can learn from the
burden of this disease

across different populations,
and any thoughts as to what might be driving that? Yeah.

It's a great question. And so let's talk about what
we expected and knew, and then let's talk about what
we didn't expect,

or maybe we should
have expected, but hadn't explicitly
been discussing.

On the issue of older people
and immunocompromised, or people with chronic disease, there are
a couple points I want to make.

One is, we saw that data
coming out of China. We saw it coming out of Italy. It's come out again in the US.

There are two things that
maybe everybody doesn't know. One is what we've
seen in the US and

in Western European
countries is that the number of young, healthy people who
have gotten very, very sick

and have died is actually much
higher than we were expecting. They still are much smaller
than older people or people

with chronic disease
in terms of proportion, but it is not a
totally benign disease

for young, healthy people. We don't totally understand why. There's a small proportion who
had this incredibly vigorous

immune response, and basically
that immune response destroys their lungs, and they die.

And we don't have
a good alternative, and immunomodulating
drugs so far

haven't had much of an impact,
not that we've studied it all that effectively. But there is this group,
and we don't get it.

So I think it's
not totally benign for young, healthy people. Second is this issue of
older, or immunocompromised,

or chronic disease. It's a pretty large group. So for instance, people say,
well, people who are over 65.

OK, well, that's a good
chunk of Americans as it is. Then we also talk about
people between 40 and 59

who have any kind
of chronic disease. And then you start saying,
what kind of chronic disease, and you say, people with
hypertension or diabetes.

Well, almost 40% of
males between 40 and 59 have hypertension. That's a lot of people.

And when you start
adding it up, you start getting into numbers like
maybe 100 to 120 million people

are at risk. That's a third of the entire
population, and almost half of the adult population.

So when you have close-- somewhere between
a third and half of the adult population
who are high risk, that's

a pretty sizable group
that you want to try to-- and so there's
been this idea of, what if we just protect
the high risk groups

and let everybody else go out? It's hard to know how you want
a country taking a third to half of adults out of the mix.

So it's a very,
very broad group. On the issue of minorities--
specifically African-Americans,

where the data has really been
very clear, and consistent, and disturbing--

there are two sets
of data that I think are worth people understanding. One is we've seen much
higher rates of infection.

And then, given
infection, we've seen much higher rates of mortality. So two separate
set of phenomena.

Obviously, I don't have the
answers on what's going on. I have speculation, and I'll
just share them with you. One is, as you alluded to, Rob,
a lot of African-Americans,

a lot of people who
are poorer, tend to work in industries where
they can't call into work using

Zoom, where they are
on the frontlines. And so meaning they're
interacting with people,

and they're taking
off in mass transit if they live in big cities. And their ability
to social distance

is much, much more limited. Or they may have jobs, or
they may have economic means

where, if they took a month
off, or six weeks off, it would be so financially
devastating that they have to make a very, very difficult
choice-- increase their risk

of getting infected or starve. And obviously,
people will choose to try to continue making some
money to feed their families.

So that's why I think we see
higher rates of infection. But then the question is,
given the rate of infection, why do we see so much
higher mortality?

And here, I think
the chronic disease stuff-- we've been talking
about African-Americans have higher rates of
hypertension and diabetes.

There is some data, I
think, that air pollution and longstanding
exposure to air pollution

is a huge risk factor for
bad outcomes from COVID. And we know that
African-Americans--

on average-- in cities live
in neighborhoods where air pollution is much, much worse. So I think that's actually a
potentially important driver.

And then last but
not least, a lot of work we've done,
other people have done, shows that the
health care systems-- the doctors, the hospitals--

that disproportionally
care for minority patients tend to have
poorer quality care,

tend to struggle
with a lot of issues. And so you can imagine that even
at the end of everything else,

if an African-American
patient ends up in a hospital, they're more likely to end up
in a poorer quality hospital. Put it all together--
and there are probably

a whole bunch of other factors
I'm not even identifying. Put it all together, it's not a
surprise this is where we are.

But it is a huge
disappointment, and I think it's something
that we ought to address much more readily.

and so I would
encourage them to start thinking through those questions
that you'd like to ask Ashish.

And before doing that,
I want to come back to this issue, Ashish,
that you raised earlier that has been all over.

It's obviously front of
mind for so many of us, which is thinking
about how do we balance the management of this
crisis with the eventual need

to reopen our economy
and our society? And my sense is, given
the number of things

that have been written by
any number of observers, clinical or otherwise, there are
a lot of blueprints out there.

What would you see as
some of the key aspects of your blueprint
for how we should think about the
reopening of either parts

or all of our economy? Yeah. Great question. So just this past
weekend, I was speaking

to several different governors
about what they should be looking for and when to reopen.

And what I try to say to them
is that there is no magic date, there is no magic moment.

And that it's a
series of trade-offs, as all complex things are.

And the longer you
wait, and the more time

you spend getting
ready for opening, the better the chances
that you can stay open.

So my line on this has been,
you can open whenever you want. The question isn't,
can you open.

It's, can you stay open. And can you stay open, because
I believe-- and I'm not

and have to shut
down for four months, in many ways, that's much
worse than an initial delay in opening, and if
you can stay open.

It's that uncertainty in the
opening and closing that's actually got
additional problems.

So what are the metrics you want
to look for to open, and then what does opening look like,
and then how do you stay open?

So what experts have been
arguing is you want to see declining number of new
cases for at least 14 that's.

Why 14 days? 14 days. It sort of gets you a couple
of cycles of transmission,

a sense that you're-- clear evidence
that you're heading in the right direction, that
social distancing is working.

There are a lot of
reasons why 14 days. What if you did
it after 10 days? You could do it
after 10 days, just

you're increasing
your risk that you're going to get a flare-up
in a way that you won't be able to control.

Second is you want to
have ubiquitous testing. And more important-- not
more important, as important as the number of tests is you
have a really smart testing

strategy. And that essentially
is, you want to identify people
with mild symptoms, or any kind of symptoms.

You want to do
substantial contact tracing so you can
identify everybody who's been around them. And you want to be able to
isolate all those people.

And then you want to start
gearing up your health care system, because when you reopen,
cases will go up by definition,

and some people will
end up getting sick. The health systems of a
lot of cities and states are really battered right
now with the large number

of COVID patients. You want to give your system
a little bit of a chance to recover. There are doctors and nurses
working 100 hours a week.

You want to give them
a chance to rest up. You want to fill up your
supplies of PPEs and stuff,

so that if and/or when
you get another surge, you can manage it a
bit more effectively.

Again, I didn't give
you any hard numbers on any of those things. It's just the more
that you can do, the better you are
equipped to stay open.

One last point on what
reopening looks like. There are not going to be any
baseball games this summer.

Certainly not ones where people
will be going to Fenway Park. The idea of 35,000
people crowding

into a park over the
summer is a nightmare, because a few infected people
can fuel a big infection

and have the entire eastern
Massachusetts shut down. So we're not going to be
able to do things like that.

But I can imagine restaurants
and bars opening, maybe with some social
distancing built in. I can imagine people
getting together for coffee,

and people being able
to get back to work. And maybe super
crowded offices are going to be a
little-- they'll have

to put in some policies
around distancing. So there's a lot we can do
to make opening a reality.

It won't be back to normal. We will not be back
to normal until we have a vaccine, which I think
is a good 12 to 18 months away.

Well, Ashish, I
noticed in your bio that the one thing you
don't have is an MBA degree,

but you have shown
us today that you're extremely good at talking
us through the costs and benefits of a
series of very complex

and challenging both clinical
and managerial decisions. And so now I want to unleash
some of our resident experts

to ask questions. And so I will turn
to Willy to see if we have any questions
from our first-year students.

Thank you, Rob. If you're an RC with a
question for Professor Jha, please click on the raised
hand icon on the toolbar

at the bottom of your screen. And because our time is limited,
please no long preambles. Just pose your
question concisely.

When I call you,
I will unmute you, and then you will have
to respond on that.
Let's start with Suhayl.

Hi, thank you. I just want to ask a question
on this last point in terms of easing social distancing and
the scale of the testing that

needs to happen for that. What kind of timelines could
we be looking at in order to get this testing in place,
and maybe more specifically--

as you said, there's a bit of
difference of a gathering of 10 versus 100 people. So what do we have
to believe in order

to think that say,
come September, that having 90, 95 people
in a classroom together

would be possible? Yeah. I'm largely ignoring--
I've been asked

by a whole bunch of
university leaders about, are we going to be able to do
classes in the fall with 90 students together?

And I'm largely punting, because
it's an honest I don't know. But I can talk about
what it might take.

So right now, we're doing about
130,000 to 150,000 tests a day.

We've ballparked that as
a country, we should be-- if we could get to about 500,000
tests a day by the time we

reopen-- so with our disease numbers
will have come down-- we should have enough testing
that we can more or less

get through the summer. We can have-- if
somebody wakes up with a sore throat and a
fever, they can get tested, their contacts can get
tested, and there aren't

going to be major delays. That we can do the things that
we need to do to keep things

open over the summer. I think that number
of 500,000 is doable. It's not totally easy,
but I think it's doable

by, let's say, June 1. A lot of governors, of course,
are itching to go by May 15,

and it's not a yes or no. If we're at 400,000 by
May 15, that might be OK.

But as soon as we can
ramp up more, the better. The problem of September is
once you start getting 90,

100 students, you really need--
in order for that to be safe, the amount of infection in the
community has to be really,

really low, and one of-- or the amount of
immunity in the community has to be really, really high.

And I don't know
how much immunity there will be
because I don't know how many people are
infected right now, or have been infected.

But we'll all know more in
the next two to four weeks, because the serology testing
is starting to really ramp up.

So that will help us
make better decisions. And it is entirely possible
that if a reasonable number of people have been
infected by then,

and that we have fabulous
testing by September, we could potentially--
and number of infections

in the community are low,
we could run MBA classes with 90 students
in the classroom.

Maybe we'd have to
think about splitting it into two groups of 45 and a bit
more spacing between students.

I can imagine those
kinds of changes. But we should be able to have
students on campus in the fall.

But it depends on
a bunch of things, including things we're going
to learn relatively soon. Our next question is
from Camille Gregory.
Go ahead, please.

Thank you for joining us. I'm curious about some of
the longer-term impacts on how our health
care system works.

Specifically, what do you think
it would look like in terms of how we train
medical professionals,

and things like
scope of practice changes that we've seen
waivers of right now, but what will that look
like in the future.

Yeah, fabulous question. And obviously, we're still
very much in the early days of this pandemic, and the
effects of the pandemic

on the health system-- well, let's just say this. The epidemic will be
with us for at least

another 12-plus months. So we're going to be
in this funny state,

and managing the disease
outbreak, at least for a good 'nother year or so. And we've made a bunch of policy
changes to better equip us.
